section.title: OpenGL Plot
section.para: This tutorial was started from the default settings in the June 9, 2008 build of GMAT.

section.title: Overview
section.para: Without OpenGL Plots, you would have no way of visualizing your spacecraft as it traveled along its trajectory. OpenGL Plots also have a multitude of options that allow you to customize your view of the spacecraft. This makes these types of plots very useful and in most cases necessary to using GMAT.

section.title: Listing of Objects and Commands that interact

listitem.para: Spacecraft
Any spacecraft in your mission is available to the OpenGL Plot for display
Solar System
The Sun and all of the Planets may be plotted or referenced in the OpenGL Plot
If you add any Barrycenters or Libration Points, they will also be available for plotting and reference
Coordinate Systems
Both View Definition and View Up Definition may use the three default or user added coordinate systems

section.title: Using the GUI
section.para: The OpenGL Plots dialog box is quite extensive and one of the largest in GMAT. The below bullets outline each option available to you and how they all work. Refer to the screen shot below this list if you need a reference as you read. The box itself is split into several Group boxes which in turn contain up to several fields each. All of this allows you to not only change what is shown in the plot, but also how far away you view the object(s) and from what direction. There is a great deal of functionality beyond this as well.

When you have a plot open, you may change your view using the mouse. Left click on the plot and move the mouse while still holding down the button. This will change the view point of the plot. Right click on the plot and again while holding the button down, move the mouse to the left to zoom in and to the left to zoom out.

listitem.para: Plot Option - Group Box
Collect data every BLANK step - Field
This value determines how many integration steps are taken between the drawing of a point on the plot. Basically, the greater this number, the less precise the plot is and the faster it will run.
Update plot every BLANK cycle - Field
This value represents the number of integration steps taken between the plot's refreshing. This means that the plot will be redrawn with the new points from the data collected above.
Number of points to redraw - Field

This value represents how many previously collected plotting points will be shown. If set to 0, all points will be drawn. If set to some positive integer then that number of previous points will be drawn. This is useful when running a long mission when you only want the most recent information displayed.
Show Plot - Check Box
If for any reason you do not want to display the plot, uncheck this box so that the object is still present in the mission tree but will not show up as an output when the mission is run.
View Object - Group Box
Spacecraft - Field
This is a list of all Spacecraft in the resource tree. Any number of them may be added to the Selected Spacecraft Field.
Selected Spacecraft - Field
This is the list of Spacecraft that will be shown in the OpenGL Plot, as long as the Draw Object Check box is selected. These are added from those in the Spacecraft Field.
Draw Object - Check Box

Like the Show Plot Check box does for the whole Plot, this box allows an object, whether it be a spacecraft or celestial, to be not shown in the plot if unchecked. When checked, the Plot will draw this object and its path.
Celestial Object - Field

Similar to the Spacecraft Field, this list contains all of the Celestial Bodies and points that are in the Solar System section of the resource tree. These include all of the Planets, the Sun, the Moon, and any points that you add under Special Points in the Resource tree such as Barycenters or Libration Points.
Selected Celestial Object - Field
This is a list of all Celestial Objects to be displayed in the plot. Any object in the Celestial Object field may be moved here so that you may see it.
Orbit Color - Selection

This changes the color of the line that a celestial object or spacecraft will leave behind as it travels through space. In the case of a spacecraft in a targeting or other sequence that requires multiple iterations, this selection represents the color of its final trajectory.
Target Color - Selection

A spacecraft that uses multiple iterations to achieve a targeting, optimization, or other sort of problem, can be drawn through each of its runs using the color selected here. It is a good idea to keep this color different from the spacecraft's orbit color.
Drawing Option - Group Box
Draw Wire Frame - Check Box
When selected, the Plot will display all spacecraft and celestial objects as wire frame models.
Draw Ecliptic Plane - Check Box
When selected, the ecliptic plane, or rather, the plane that the Earth travels in around the Sun, will be displayed.
Draw XY Plane - Check Box
This will draw a wire mesh plane in the plane of the X and Y axes that the Plot is referencing as the View Definition Coordinate System.
Draw Axes - Check Box
This will draw the axes of the selected coordinate system.
Draw Grid - Check Box
When selected, this option will have GMAT draw a longitude and latitude grid in the Plot.
Draw Sun Line - Check Box
When checked, this option will draw a line at all times between the centers of the Earth and Sun.
View Definition - Group Box
Coordinate System - Drop Down Menu
This is what coordinate system will be used in the
View Point Reference - Drop Down Menu
This is set to the center of the Plot's coordinate system by default but may be changed to any spacecraft or celestial object. It is where the View Point Vector is referenced from.
View Point Vector - Drop Down Menu

The View Point Vector is where you will view the Plot from. It is the camera location, so to speak, with respect to the View Point Reference whether it be the center of the plot's coordinate system or defined by you above in the View Point Reference drop down menu.
View Point Vector - Fields
These are the fields beside the View Point Vector drop down menu where you define the actual view point vector in the X, Y, Z format.
View Scale Factor - Field
The View Scale Factor is basically a multiplier of the View Point Vector. For example, if you put 5 as a value here then you will see the objects 5 times further away.
View Direction - Drop Down Menu
This allows you to point the direction of view for the plot, the camera, toward the direction of your choosing. This may be towards a spacecraft or celestial object.
View Option - Group Box
Use Initial View Def. - Check Box

Use Initial View Definition is very useful when doing multiple runs of a mission. If left checked, your view of the plot will always start out the same. If you uncheck this box and move your view of the plot with the mouse once the mission has finished running, you can re-run the mission and the view will stay where you left it.
View Up Definition - Group Box
Coordinate System - Drop Down Menu

The View Definition group box only gives you where your view of the plot is located from but does not tell GMAT which way is up within that view. This drop down menu allows you to set what coordinate system is referenced when setting the up direction. This will usually be the same coordinate system as used to define the View Direction.
Axis - Drop Down Menu
This tells GMAT what axis of the View Up Definition Coordinate System to point up in your plot.

section.title: Reference Tables

entry.para: The DataCollectFrequency field allows the user to define how data is collected for plotting. It is often inefficient to draw every ephemeris point associated with a trajectory. Often, drawing a smaller subset of the data still results in smooth trajectory plots, while executing more quickly. The DataCollectFrequency is an integer that represents how often to collect data and store for plotting. If DataCollectFrequency is set to 10, then Data is collected every 10 integration steps.

The UpdatePlotFrequency field allows the user to specify how often to update an OpenGL plot is updated with new data collected during the process of propagating spacecraft and running a mission. Data is collected for a plot according the value defined by DataCollectFrequency. An OpenGL plot is updated with the new data, according to the value set in UpdatePlotFrequency. If UpdatePlotFrequency is set to 10 and DataCollectFrequency is set to 2, then the plot is updated with new data every 20 (10*2) integration steps.

When NumPointsToRedraw is set to zero, all ephemeris points are drawn. When NumPointsToRedraw is set to a positive integer, say 10 for example, only the last 10 collected data points are drawn. See DataCollectFrequency for explanation of how data is collected for an OpenGL plot.

The ShowPlot field allows the user to turn off a plot for a particular run, without deleting the plot object, or removing it from the script. If you select true, then the plot will be shown. If you select false, then the plot will not be shown.

The Add subfield adds a spacecraft,celestial body, libration point,or barycenter to a plot. When creating a plot the Earth is added as a default body and may be removed by using the Remove command. The user can add a spacecraft, celestial body, libration point, or barycenter to a plot by using the name used to create the object. The GUI's Selected field is the equivalent of the script's Add field. In the event of no Add command or no objects in the Selected field, GMAT should run without the OpenGL plot and a warning message displayed in the message window. The following warning message is sufficient: OpenGL plot will be turned off. No object has been selected for plotting.
Options: { Any object included in the Add list }

The Remove subfield removes a spacecraft,celestial body, libration point, or barycenter from a plot. The user can remove any object that has been added to a plot by using the name used to add the object.
When the WireFrame field is set to On, celestial bodies are drawn using a wireframe model. When the WireFrame field is set to Off, then celestial bodies are drawn using a full map.
Options: { On , Off } Note: Only allowed for OpenGL plots with Coordinate Systems that use the MJ2000Eq axis system

The EclipticPlane field allows the user to tell GMAT to draw a grid representing the ecliptic plane in an OpenGL plot. Note, the ecliptic plane can currently only be drawn for plots whose coordinate system uses the MJ2000Eq axis system.
The XYPlane flag allows the user to tell GMAT to draw a grid representing the XY-plane of the coordinate system selected under the CoordinateSystem field of the OpenGL plot.
The Axis flag allows the user to tell GMAT to draw the Cartesian axis system associated with the coordinate system selected under the CoordinateSystem field of an OpenGL plot.
The Grid flag allows the user to tell GMAT to draw a grid representing the longitude and latitude lines celestial bodies added to an OpenGL plot.
The EarthSunLines allows the user to tell GMAT to draw a line that starts at the center of Earth and points towards the Sun.

The SolverIterations field determines whether or not perturbed trajectories are plotted during a solver (Targeter, Optimize) sequence. When SolverIterations is set to On, solver iterations are shown on the plot. When SolverIterations is Off, the solver iterations are not shown on the plot.
Options: { Any default or user defined coordinate system }

The CoordinateSystem field on an OpenGL plot allows the user to select which coordinate system to use to draw the plot data. A coordinate system is defined as an origin and an axis system, and the CoordinateSystem field allows the user to determine the origin and axis system of an OpenGL plot. See the CoordinateSystem object fields for information of defining different types of coordinate systems.

The ViewPointReference field is an optional field that allows the user to change the reference point from which ViewPointVector is measured. ViewPointReference} defaults to the origin of the coordinate system for the plot. A ViewPointReference can be any spacecraft, celestial body, libration point, or barycenter.

The product of ViewScaleFactor and ViewPointVector field determines the view point location with respect to ViewPointReference. ViewPointVector can be a vector, or any of the following objects: spacecraft,celestial body, libration point,or barycenter. The location of the Viewpoint in three-space is defined as the vector addition of ViewPointReference, and the vector defined by product of ViewScaleFactor and ViewPointVector in the coordinate system chosen by the user.
The ViewScaleFactor field scales ViewPointVector before adding it to ViewPointReference. The ViewScaleFactor allows the user to back away from an object to fit in the field of view.

The ViewDirection field allows the user to select the direction of view in an OpenGL plot. The user can specify the view direction by choosing an object to point at such as a spacecraft,celestial body, libration point,or barycenter. Alternatively, the user can specify a vector of the form [x y z]. If the user specification of ViewDirection, ViewPointReference, and ViewPointVector, results in a zero vector, GMAT uses [0 0 10000] for ViewDirection.

The UseInitialView field allows the user to control the view of an OpenGL plot between multiple runs of a mission sequence. The first time a specific OpenGL plot is created, GMAT will automatically use the view as defined by the fields associated with View Definition, View Up Direction, and Field of View. However, if the user changes the view using the mouse, GMAT will retain this view upon rerunning the mission if UseInitialView is set to false. If UseInitialView is set to true, the view for an OpenGL plot will be returned to the view defined by the initial settings.

section.para: Fields Associated with View Up Definition

entry.para: Options: { Any default or user defined coordinate system }

The ViewUpCoordinateSystem and ViewUpAxis fields are used to determine which direction appears as up in an OpenGL plot and together with the fields associated the the View Direction, uniquely define the view. The fields associated with the View Definition allow the user to define the point of view in 3-space, and the direction of the line of sight. However, this information alone is not enough to uniquely define the view. We also must provide how the view is oriented about the line of sight. This is accomplished by defining what direction should appear as the up direction in the plot and is configured using the ViewUpCoordinateSystem field and the ViewUpAxis field. The ViewUpCoordinateSystem allows the user to select a coordinate system to define the up direction. Most of the time this system will be the same as the coordinate system chosen under the CoordinateSystem field.

The ViewUpAxis allows the user to define which axis of the ViewUpCoordinateSystem that will appear as the up direction in an OpenGL plot. See the comments under ViewUpCoordinateSystem for more details of fields used to determine the up direction in an OpenGL plot.
